topic: Web Security: XSS, CSRF, and Best Practices
detailedSummary: Web security protects applications and users from attacks. XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) injects malicious scripts into web pages. Prevention: sanitize user input, escape output, use Content Security Policy (CSP). CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) tricks users into performing unwanted actions. Prevention: CSRF tokens, SameSite cookies, verify origin. SQL Injection attacks databases through input. Prevention: parameterized queries, input validation. Authentication attacks target login systems. Prevention: strong passwords, rate limiting, account lockouts. HTTPS encrypts data in transit. Security headers (CSP, HSTS, X-Frame-Options) protect against various attacks. Input validation and sanitization prevent malicious data. Dependency vulnerabilities require regular updates. Secrets management stores API keys securely. Security best practices: principle of least privilege, defense in depth, regular updates, security audits. Understanding web security is essential for building safe, trustworthy applications.
whyItMatters: Web security is critical for protecting user data and application integrity - security vulnerabilities can lead to data breaches, financial loss, and loss of user trust.

assignments.title: Secure a Web Application
assignments.description: Identify and fix security vulnerabilities in a web application, implementing security best practices.
tasks: Identify potential XSS vulnerabilities and implement input sanitization
Protect against CSRF attacks using tokens or SameSite cookies
Implement input validation and output encoding
Add security headers (CSP, HSTS) to protect against attacks
Conduct a security audit of an application and document vulnerabilities and fixes

quizzes.question: What is XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)?
options: An attack that injects malicious scripts into web pages
quizzes.explanation: XSS is an attack where malicious scripts are injected into web pages, often through user input, and executed in other users' browsers.

quizzes.question: CSRF tokens prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks by ensuring requests come from legitimate sources.
quizzes.explanation: True. CSRF tokens are unique values included in forms that verify requests originate from the legitimate application, preventing forged requests.

quizzes.question: What is the primary defense against SQL Injection?
quizzes.explanation: Parameterized queries (prepared statements) and input validation prevent SQL injection by ensuring user input is treated as data, not executable code.
